citation.article-title: Halomonas korlensis sp. nov., a moderately halophilic, denitrifying bacterium isolated from saline and alkaline soil.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Halomonas korlensis sp. nov.
Halomonas korlensis (kor.len′sis. N.L. fem. adj. korlensis pertaining to Korla, in north-western China, where the type strain was isolated).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-motile and non-spore-forming rods or short rods and 0.8–1.0×1.3–1.7 μm.
No flagella are observed (see Supplementary Fig. S1).
Does not accumulate poly-β-hydroxyalkanoate and does not produce exopolysaccharides.
On MH agar, produces circular, convex and orange-coloured colonies.
Moderately halophilic, capable of growing in salt concentrations of 0.5–25 % (w/v); no growth occurs in the absence of NaCl.
Grows within the temperature range of 4–43 °C and at pH values between 6.0 and 10.0.
Optimum growth occurs at 6.0–10.0 % total salts, 30 °C and pH 8.5–9.0.
Chemo-organotrophic.
Metabolism is respiratory, with oxygen, nitrate or nitrite as terminal electron acceptors.
Gas is produced anaerobically from nitrate.
Nitrate can be reduced to nitrite aerobically.
Cells do not grow anaerobically in the presence of fumarate.
Oxidase, catalase and urease are produced, but not o-nitrophenyl β-d-galactopyranosidase, phenylalanine deaminase, lysine decarboxylase or ornithine decarboxylase.
Variable reaction for oxidation/fermentation of d-glucose.
Tween 20 is hydrolysed, but not gelatin, casein, starch, Tween 80, DNA, lecithin or aesculin.
H2S, indole and Voges–Proskauer tests are negative; methyl red test is positive.

Acid is produced from d-fructose and d-glucose, but not from adonitol, l-arabinose, myo-inositol, lactose, maltose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, melezitose, l-rhamnose, d-salicin, d-sorbitol, sorbose, trehalose or cellobiose.
A variable reaction is found for d-galactose and sucrose.

The following compounds can be used as sole carbon and energy sources: d-fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, maltose, d-mannose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, ribose, acetate, citrate, formate, fumarate, gluconate, malonate, propionate, succinate, ethanol, glycerol, myo-inositol, pectin, sucrose, malate, lactate and pyruvate, but not cellobiose, starch, d-xylose or oxalate. d-melezitose, d-salicin, adonitol and d-mannitol are weakly utilized; a variable reaction is noted for aesculin, l-arabinose, lactose, trehalose and sorbitol.
The following compounds are used as sole carbon, nitrogen and energy sources: l-alanine, l-isoleucine, l-serine and l-valine, but not l-cysteine or l-histidine.
Variable reaction for l-lysine and l-methionine.

Cells are susceptible to amoxicillin (25 μg ml−1), ampicillin (25 μg ml−1), cefoxitin (30 μg ml−1), cefotaxime (30 μg ml−1), chloramphenicol (30 μg ml−1), kanamycin (30 μg ml−1), nitrofurantoin (100 μg ml−1), polymyxin B (300 U), rifampicin (30 μg ml−1), streptomycin (50 μg ml−1), sulphamide (250 μg ml−1) and spectinomycin (100 μg ml−1), but not to carbenicillin (100 μg ml−1), erythromycin (30 μg ml−1), nalidixic acid (10 μg ml−1), tobramycin (30 μg ml−1), neomycin (10 μg ml−1), tetracycline (12.5 μg ml−1), bacitracin (30 μg ml−1) or furandantin (50 μg ml−1).
The major fatty acids are C18 : 1ω8t, C16 : 0 and C18 : 1ω7t.
The DNA G+C contents are between 65.1–65.7 mol% (Tm method).
The type strain, XK1T (=CGMCC 1.6981T=DSM 19633T) and four other reference strains were isolated from a saline and alkaline soil in Korla, north-western China.
For the type strain, XK1T, acid can also be produced from d-galactose, but not from sucrose.
l-Arabinose, trehalose and l-lysine are weakly utilized, but not aesculin, lactose, sorbitol or l-methionine.
Acid is produced from d-glucose by fermentation.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 65.3 mol%.
